pull.title: Only allocate a LevelDB block cache if LevelDB will actually use it
pull.body:
When snappy compression is disabled, LevelDB does not use a block cache. This PR avoids wasting memory reserved for the block cache in that situation, and gives it to the write buffer instead.

Unfortunately this behavior is not documented (I have filed a bug upstream already). You can see [here](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/leveldb/blob/bitcoin-fork/util/env_posix.cc#L202) that `PosixMmapReadableFile` takes a `scratch` argument that is unused. This isn't by accident; the return value of the method is compared against the supplied buffer [here](https://github.com/bitcoin-core/leveldb/blob/bitcoin-fork/table/format.cc#L109) to determine whether the block cache should be used.

Giving more memory to the write buffer is good for a number of reasons. Among them: LevelDB checks reads against the mem table holding current writes, so the write buffer acts as an LRU within LevelDB.

verification.payload:
tree 2d460a7d9cf119ce338f8087047f49a71986d0c9
parent 615f7c288414a89cd1dec1d67e0f84abe2fb4c6d
author Evan Klitzke <evan@eklitzke.org> 1522303513 -0700
committer Evan Klitzke <evan@eklitzke.org> 1524094214 -0700

Only give LevelDB a block cache if LevelDB will actually use it.

On systems that use mmap LevelDB does not use a block cache. On these systems we
give the memory instead to the write buffer, where it will be used more
effectively.

events.message:
Only give LevelDB a block cache if LevelDB will actually use it.

On systems that use mmap LevelDB does not use a block cache. On these systems we
give the memory instead to the write buffer, where it will be used more
effectively.

events.body: <!--5d09a71f8925f3f132321140b44b946d-->The last travis run for this pull request was 93 days ago and is thus outdated. To trigger a fresh travis build, this pull request should be closed and re-opened.

comments.body: Could use `__LP64__` macro instead? See https://stackoverflow.com/a/682955.

It sounds like that refers to the data model based on the name, e.g. it sounds like you would have `__LLP64__` on a 64-bit system using an LLP integer model. Additionally the LevelDB code uses `sizeof` in its check, so the code as-is is definitely consistent with the logic used within LevelDB.
